title: GetUp decides to go easy on pro-coal Labor MPs
text:
"Undoubtedly we would do things differently if we had that opportunity again," he said.

Since its election defeat, a number of Labor MPs and identities have acknowledged the need for the party to shed left-wing policies and tack back towards the political centre.

Climate policy has emerged as the latest battleground with Mr Fitzgibbon, the party's resources spokesman and long-serving MP for NSW's coal-mining heartland in the Hunter Valley, urging Labor water down its emissions reduction ambition and adopt the government's target of a 26 to 28 per cent cut by 2030.

Asked whether GetUp would campaign against Mr Fitzgibbon and other pro-coal Labor MPs and candidates, Mr Oosting said while the group did not support the veteran MP's call for lower emission targets, the heat would stay on the Coalition over climate change policy.

"Our immediate priority has to be on the government. The government are the ones who need to act on climate change. We need to focus on whose in power," he said.

Resources Minister Matt Canavan said Mr Oosting's stance proved two things.

"One: GetUp is just a front for the Labor Party. Two: Joel isn’t really going to stand up and fight for coal jobs so that’s why the green activists at GetUp don’t see him as a threat," he said.

Mr Oosting said GetUp spent $3.5 million on its campaign relying largely on small donors, in stark contrast to mining magnate Clive Palmer who splurged $60 million and has claimed credit for helping turn voters against Bill Shorten.

Advertisement

"There’s simply no level playing field when a Clive Palmer can wash our whole country’s smartphones, laptops, and just about every spare billboard in an icky sea of yellow," Mr Oosting said.

"Essential as donations reforms are, expenditure caps tackle the “demand-side” of the problem. If politicians can’t spend, they don’t need to raise it. If they don’t need to raise it, wealthy donors and corporates won’t have the power to subvert democracy."

Mr Morrison hinted earlier this year at holding a fourth inquiry into GetUp's claim it is politically independent and not associated with Labor and the Greens, accusing it of misogyny and bullying against another conservative MP, Nicolle Flint.

But Mr Oosting said the claims were "completely without substance". He said the repeated inquiries into GetUp's bona fides were intended to "smear, discredit, cast a slur and raise doubt".
description: The left-wing activist group risks claims of hypocrisy because it won't protest against Labor MPs over climate change.
